PURPOSE
The purpose of this policy is to establish requirements for PeaceHealth's cyber security incident response to aid in protecting the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of PeaceHealth's information systems.
DEFINITIONS
•
Caregiver: PeaceHealth employee, volunteer, trainee, and other persons whose conduct, in the performance of work for PeaceHealth, is under the direct control of PeaceHealth, regardless of whether they are paid by PeaceHealth.
•
Covered Person: Includes caregivers, non-employed medical directors, locum tenens and relief providers, members of the Board of PeaceHealth and committees with Board-delegated powers, members of the Community (Network) Board of Directors, members of the Foundation Board of Directors, PeaceHealth representatives of PeaceHealth Joint Ventures or partially or wholly owned PeaceHealth subsidiaries, volunteers, trainees and medical students, any others designated by PeaceHealth's Board or leadership, contracted providers, medical staff members, officers, Board Members, and Directors of Affiliated Organizations, joint ventures, or partially or wholly owned PeaceHealth subsidiaries.
POLICY
It is the policy of PeaceHealth that the following requirements are implemented to support PeaceHealth information system incident response:
1.
PeaceHealth provides cyber security incident response training to information system users that is consistent with the individual user's assigned roles and responsibilities in cyber security incident response.
2.
PeaceHealth tests cyber security incident response capabilities and documents the results annually at a minimum.
3.
PeaceHealth implements cyber security incident handling capabilities for security incidents which:
a.
Includes preparation, detection and analysis, containment, eradication, and recovery;
b.
Coordinates cyber security incident handling activities with contingency planning activities; and
c.
Implements changes to incident response procedures, training, and testing based on lessons learned from past and ongoing incident handling activities.
4.
PeaceHealth tracks and documents cyber security incidents.
5.
PeaceHealth requires cover persons to report suspected information or cyber security incidents in accordance with the PeaceHealth Reporting Information Privacy and Security Incidents procedure.
6.
PeaceHealth reports security incident information in accordance with legal requirements, such as the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) Breach Notification Rule.
7.
PeaceHealth develops a Cyber Security Incident Response Plan in accordance with the Cyber Incident Response and Management Standards Policy.
8.
PeaceHealth ensures that the Cyber Security Incident Response Plan is reviewed and approved by senior leadership, including but not limited to the VP Information Security and the Chief Information Officer (CIO).
9.
PeaceHealth distributes copies of the Cyber Security Incident Response plan to personnel responsible for implementing emergency response, including members of the cyber security incident response team and other key personnel.
10.
PeaceHealth reviews the Cyber Security Incident Response Plan annually or after significant change to the information system.
11.
PeaceHealth updates the Cyber Security Incident Response Plan as deemed necessary after review or after plan implementation, execution, or testing.
12.
PeaceHealth ensures that changes to the Cyber Security Incident Response Plan are communicated to the cyber security incident response team members and other appropriate personnel.
13.
PeaceHealth protects the Cyber Security Incident Response Plan from unauthorized disclosure and modification.
Compliance
Individuals included in the scope of this policy are required to comply with the policy and all associated policies, standards, and procedures. Violations are subject to removal of access and/or corrective action, up to and including termination of employment or other business relationship with PeaceHealth. Any deviations from security standards observed in the production environment must be communicated to the Information Security department immediately upon discovery. If an exception to this policy is necessary, it must be submitted in accordance with the Information Security Policy and Standards Exceptions policy.
